posts.cooked:
After a long discussion in this thread I made a pull request to fix a problem in libsignal, affecting all gappless android devices. To support this pull request it would be great if
some people could test the fix and verify if it works correctly.

To paticipate in the test you need a device where you can uninstall signal and install a patched version. Note that the patched version is signed by me and not ows, so
you can’t just install the patched version over the current installation. Be aware that this is a test build. Do not use it on a device that you depend on! Keep a backup!

You can download the patched version here.

To execute the test on a device without gapps you have to do the following steps:

  • With the official version still installed, give your device some quiet time (not much interaction or network changes for a longer time; an hour would be great)
  • Take a debug log
  • Verify that you have the following exception about every minute in the logfile (in the logcat section) to know your device is affected by the problem:

WebSocketConnection: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Receiver not registered:
org.whispersystems.signalservice.api.util.RealtimeSleepTimer$AlarmReceiver@ab5dd6e

  • uninstall Signal and install the patched version
  • use it for a longer time; a day or so would be great; again with longer periods without much interaction or network changes
  • Take another debug log
  • Verify that the exception disappeared.

In the end post the following information here:

  • your device name and android version
  • both debug logs
  • whether the patch works for you

If you use a device with gapps you should not be affected by this problem, but it would be great to have some people still testing it to see if I didn’t break something. Therefore follow the following steps:

  • uninstall official signal and install the patched version (no need for a debug log defore the test as it should not show an error anyway)
  • set the android screen timeout to 3 or 4 minutes
  • open signal and let it idle in the foreground for 3 or 4 minutes (the code I patched only runs on normal devices as long as the app is in the foreground)
  • take a debug log
  • Verify that everything worked fine. When the app does nothing but wait in the foreground, you should have the following lines in the log (in the logcat section) every 55 seconds:

04-01 09:03:44.925 14442 12331 W WebSocketConnection: Sending keep alive…
04-01 09:03:44.989 14442 12311 W WebSocketConnection: WSC onMessage()
04-01 09:03:44.989 14442 12311 W WebSocketConnection: Message Type: 2
04-01 09:03:44.992 14442 12335 W WebSocketConnection: Sending keep alive…
04-01 09:03:45.037 14442 12309 W WebSocketConnection: WSC onMessage()
04-01 09:03:45.037 14442 12309 W WebSocketConnection: Message Type: 2
04-01 09:03:49.984 14442 14467 W IncomingMessageObserver: Application level read timeout…
04-01 09:03:49.987 14442 14467 D IncomingMessageObserver: Network requirement: true, app visible: true, gcm disabled: false
04-01 09:03:49.988 14442 14467 I IncomingMessageObserver: Reading message…

  • Then use it for a day or so to see whether everything works as normal
  • take another debug log

In the end post the following information here:

  • your device name and android version
  • the debug logs
  • whether still everything works

Please post only test results here. If you have questions or uncertainness, please post it in the the other thread.

Thanks in advance for your support!

Edit: I updated the apk to fix a little problem. If you not yet started the test please use the new one (see GitHub - theBoatman/fixing-signal) and state which version you used in the test report.

• OnePlus 6
  • Android 9 (HavocOS)
  • no Gapps
  • AFWall+ (UID 1000 and CaptivePortalLogin has no internet)
  • Patched Version Log (4.38.3)

It worked: Exceptions with official website release (v4.39.4), no exceptions with your test version (v2):

  • Samsung S3 (LTE) i9305
  • LineageOS 14.1-20170927-NIGHTLY-i9305 (based on Android 7.1.2)
  • No GApps

Logcat of your test version: several hours and some minutes
Logat of the official version: several hours

More lengthy logs will follow. (done)

Unfortunately I can’t provide a log for the official signal version but I can confirm that I was affected by exception. I have been using your version for over a month now and haven’t encountered any issues so far.

  • OnePlus 3
  • LineageOS 16 (multiple version from early April to late May)
  • no Google Apps, no microG
  • Signal version used for the log: 4.40.1-sleepfix.apk

posts.cooked:
theBoatman:

If you use a device with gapps you should not be affected by this problem, but it would be great to have some people still testing it to see if I didn’t break something.

I have two test-sessions to report, one for myself on a test-handset and one for @johanw666 on another test-handset.

We did not follow the proper instructions! instead...
theBoatman:

Therefore follow the following modified(!) steps:

  •  uninstall official signal and  (not necessary)
  • install the x1pre5 apk which contains “the same” exact code as the patched version (specifically the current contents of pr#70 were merged into 4.42.3 signal-android and 2.13.5 libsignal-service-java)
  • (no need for a debug log defore the test as it should not show an error anyway plus no need to uninstall stock signalapp anymore, either)

Test procedure, followed by johanw666:

  • become seriously ill
  • heroically capture debuglog anyways :-)
  • no special test-procedures followed because 5cd forgot to mention any
  • debuglog should show about 17 hours of test-usage

Test procedure, followed by 5cd:

  • set the android screen timeout to 3 or 4 5 minutes
  • open signal x1pre5 and let it idle in the foreground for 3 or 4 5 minutes (the code I patched only runs on normal devices as long as the app is in the foreground), at which point screen went dark
  • take a debug log at about the 8-minute-mark, i.e. after 3 mins darkness
  • Verify that everything worked fine. When the app does nothing but wait in the foreground, you should (and did) have the following lines in the log (in the logcat section) every 55 seconds (well… my device shows WebSocketConnection attempts every 55 seconds but it shows IncomingMessageObserver every 60 seconds… other than that this is just what I saw):

04-01 09:03:44.925 14442 12331 W WebSocketConnection: Sending keep alive…
04-01 09:03:44.989 14442 12311 W WebSocketConnection: WSC onMessage()
04-01 09:03:44.989 14442 12311 W WebSocketConnection: Message Type: 2
04-01 09:03:44.992 14442 12335 W WebSocketConnection: Sending keep alive…
04-01 09:03:45.037 14442 12309 W WebSocketConnection: WSC onMessage()
04-01 09:03:45.037 14442 12309 W WebSocketConnection: Message Type: 2
04-01 09:03:49.984 14442 14467 W IncomingMessageObserver: Application level read timeout…
04-01 09:03:49.987 14442 14467 D IncomingMessageObserver: Network requirement: true, app visible: true, gcm disabled: false
04-01 09:03:49.988 14442 14467 I IncomingMessageObserver: Reading message…

  • Then prior to that! use it for a day or so to see whether everything works as normal
  • take another debug log did it in reverse order… used for 20 hours, worked fine, then performed idle-for-N-minutes test at the end, worked as expected

“In the end, post the following info…”

  • your device name and android version
    • 5cd: Alcatel a574bL w/ android 7.1.1, stock ROM, with playSvcs
  • the debug logs
    • 5cd: used ~20 hours, then sent test-message at 06:03, then idle’d in foreground until 06:08 screen-dim, waited another 128 seconds with black screen, then captured this debuglog …which shows idle-test at the end, plus 20 hours of usage before the idle-test (w/ sleepfix in place & no degradation)
  • whether still everything works
    • 5cd: yup, detected no issues, whistle-clean debuglogs

debuglog-excerpt of the 5cd idle-test portion, which works as expected

posts.name: BBou
posts.cooked: @theBoatman thanks for continuously providing updated .apks. I don’t know how to make this issue more visible, but should the community be working on automatic builds merges from the official android app into your branch through CI? Or are you willing to continue providings builds?

LocherInReifen:

@theBoatman thanks for continuously providing updated .apk s. I don’t know how to make this issue more visible, but should the community be working on automatic builds merges from the official android app into your branch through CI? Or are you willing to continue providings builds?

To be honest I am clueless about how to proceed with this. If there is interest I can continue publish builds (I need them for myself and publishing them is not a big extra effort.) but I probably will not be always 100% uptodate. If anyone has a better idea I would be happy to hear.

link_counts.title: Very high battery drain on 4.34.8 without Google Play services
Very high battery drain on 4.34.8 without Google Play services

posts.name: BBou
posts.cooked:
I am as clueless as you, sadly. The devs haven’t given a single response it seems, which is regrettable.

The only suggestion I have would take some work: automated releases of your fork

Maybe there’s a github integration that can do that, but using gitlab, there’s the possibility of:

  1. automatically pulling changes from automated merges of signalapp/Signal-Android master
  2. creating merge-requests with the gitlab API when a release has been tagged in the master branch
  3. adding CI that generates and signs an APK when the merge-request is successfully merged
  4. pushing that APK to github (using the CI as well)

I’m not an android dev, so I don’t know the build procedure, because your patch seems to be a lib used by the android app.

If you don’t have time to do that, if you give me links to how to build the project, I’ll be able to help and provide all the necessary steps + scripts to do what I described above - albeit not immediately, I’m busy for the next 2 weeks or so.

All the above would allow to provide a guide for others to easily provide the own signed Signal-Android apps with pull requests that the Signal devs still haven’t gotten around to merging.

Just out curiosity, @haffenloher you seem to be in contact with the dev team. Do you have any thoughts on how to get these changes into the official version without resorting to a fork?

link_counts.title: Very high battery drain on 4.34.8 without Google Play services

posts.cooked:
LocherInReifen:

Just out curiosity, @haffenloher you seem to be in contact with the dev team. Do you have any thoughts on how to get these changes into the official version without resorting to a fork?

If I remember correctly, at some point when we were about to start this forum, a more direct communication channel between the forum mods and the developers was part of the plan. It never actually got established, though. Not sure how I can help here, sorry

link_counts.title: Very high battery drain on 4.34.8 without Google Play services

posts.name: BBou
posts.cooked: That’s a pity. Thanks for the response and forum nonetheless. You seem to have become the forum the devs direct people to from github

Very high battery drain on 4.34.8 without Google Play services

posts.cooked:
haffenloher:

Not sure how I can help here, sorry

To sum up the current situation: There are already enough topics mentioning this problem that we can assume everybody here in the community knows the problem and nobody is able to help

In a rather desperate attempt I twittered some words about the problem in the hope to find someone outside the forum who can help, but since I do not have any follower there my range is limited. If someone here wants to support this approach you can retweet it or post something similar there.

And if anyone asks: I do not like this approach, because in my opinion the comunication should run through the forum here or github, but since there is not a single official reaction I have to assume that it does not work that way.

fancy_title: Call for testing: fixing RealtimeSleepTimer to work in concurrent threads
title: Call for testing: fixing RealtimeSleepTimer to work in concurrent threads

accepted_answer.name: link ✦
accepted_answer.excerpt:
It’s now merged in Signal 4.50.2!

github.com/signalapp/Signal-Android

fixing RealtimeSleepTimer to work in concurrent threads

signalapp:4.50.2 ← theBoatman:sleepfix
opened 09:38PM - 08 Nov 19 UTC
theBoatman
+100 -2

This pull request is the reincarnation of https://github.com/signalapp/libsignal…-service-java/pull/70 because @alan-signal requested the following changes: * Move the class RealtimeSleepTimer from from libsignal-service-java to Signal-Android * rename it to AlarmSleepTimer For any other info on this change please read [original request](https://github.com/signalapp/libsignal-service-java/pull/70), and especially [alans post](https://github.com/signalapp/libsignal-service-java/pull/70#issuecomment-551890303). I provided a [test build](https://github.com/theBoatman/fixing-signal/blob/master/Signal-website-universal-release-4.49.17-sleepfix2.apk) if anyone wants to try it out. If there is any problem or the need for further changes feel free to ask. ### First time contributor checklist - [x] I have read [how to contribute](https://github.com/signalapp/Signal-Android/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) to this project - [x] I have signed the [Contributor License Agreement](https://whispersystems.org/cla/)
